Notes: จะ is the future marker “will”; goes before the verb
Very common “will go”; can be followed by place or time
Pattern “ไป + verb” = go do something
Can mean go for a walk / stroll
Used for walking on foot, often relaxed
Polite male “I”; used by men/boys in most situations
Future marker; comes between pronoun and verb
Often followed by destination or time
Common polite “I” for women; also used in formal speech
Same future marker จะ, works the same for any subject
Can be expanded: ฉันจะไปไทย “I will go to Thailand”
